It may be more natural in your language to put the information about Eli’s ancestor’s family before the information about Eli’s family. Alternate translation: [the descendants of your ancestor, and therefore your family]

Using a common expression of his culture, Yahweh is saying **walk about** to mean “live.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [would live in my presence]

notes.orig_language_quote: חָלִ֣ילָ⁠ה לִּ֔⁠י כִּֽי־מְכַבְּדַ֥⁠י אֲכַבֵּ֖ד וּ⁠בֹזַ֥⁠י יֵקָֽלּוּ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since I honor those who honor me, but they will despise those who disdain me, profane to me!]

Yahweh is using a common expression of this culture to express horror at the idea he has just described. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [far be it from me!] or [I hope that never happens!]

Yahweh is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [profane to me to let that happen!] or [far be it from me to let that happen!]
Here the author is not using the pronoun **they** to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [will be despised]

bsb_verse_text: Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength and the strength of your father’s house, so that no one in it will reach old age.
ult_verse_text: Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your arm and the arm of the house of your father from the being of an old man in your house.

notes.note: As the Introduction to 1 Samuel discusses, Yahweh is using the word **Behold** to focus Eli’s attention on what he is about to say. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation, here and throughout the book. Alternate translation: [Now listen:]

Yahweh is using the term **days** to represent a future time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the time is coming]

Yahweh is speaking as if Eli’s strength and his family’s strength were each an **arm** that could be **cut off**. Strength, in turn, represents in this context the vigorous young men of a family. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when I will cause the vigorous young men in your family and in the house of your father to die]

bsb_verse_text: You will see distress in My dwelling place. Despite all that is good in Israel, no one in your house will ever again reach old age.
ult_verse_text: And you will see the distress of the Dwelling, in all that he will do good with Israel. And an old man will not be in your house all of the days.

notes.note: Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [I will do]

Yahweh is using the term **house** to represent Eli’s family. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in your family]
Yahweh is using the term **days** to represent time in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [ever again]

bsb_verse_text: And every one of you that I do not cut off from My altar, I will cause your eyes to fail and your heart to grieve. All your descendants will die by the sword of men.
ult_verse_text: But I will not cut off a man to you from near my altar, to make your eyes fail and to make your soul grieve. And all of the increase of your house will die {as} men.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִ֗ישׁ לֹֽא־אַכְרִ֤ית לְ⁠ךָ֙ מֵ⁠עִ֣ם מִזְבְּחִ֔⁠י לְ⁠כַלּ֥וֹת אֶת־עֵינֶ֖י⁠ךָ וְ⁠לַ⁠אֲדִ֣יב אֶת־נַפְשֶׁ֑⁠ךָ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But to make your eyes fail and to make your soul grieve, I will not cut off a man to you from near my altar]
Yahweh is speaking as if he would **cut off** people from life. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will not kill]

Yahweh is not referring to a specific **man**. He means in general the men of Eli’s family. It may be more natural in your language to express this meaning by using a plural form. Alternate translation: [But I will not cut off all the men in your family]

Yahweh is using parts of Eli and his descendants, their **eyes** and **souls**, to mean all of them in the act of weeping and grieving. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to make you and your descendants weep greatly and grieve deeply]

Yahweh is using the term **increase** to represent to further members who will be born into Eli’s family. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And all those who are born into your family]

The specific term that Yahweh uses here for **men** indicates young men. You could state this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [as young men]

bsb_verse_text: And this sign shall come to you concerning your two sons Hophni and Phinehas: They will both die on the same day.
ult_verse_text: And this {is} the sign for you that will come to the two of your sons, to Hophni and Phinehas: in one day the two of them will die.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠זֶה־לְּ⁠ךָ֣ הָ⁠א֗וֹת אֲשֶׁ֤ר יָבֹא֙ אֶל־שְׁנֵ֣י בָנֶ֔י⁠ךָ אֶל־חָפְנִ֖י וּ⁠פִֽינְחָ֑ס
notes.note: Yahweh is speaking of this **sign** as if it were a living thing that could **come** to Eli. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And when this happens to your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, it will be a sign for you]

bsb_verse_text: Then I will raise up for Myself a faithful priest. He will do whatever is in My heart and mind. And I will build for him an enduring house, and he will walk before My anointed one for all time.
ult_verse_text: And I will raise up for myself a faithful priest. He will do just as {is} in my heart and in my soul. And I will build for him an established house, and he will walk about to the face of my anointed all of the days.

notes.note: Yahweh is speaking as if he would **raise up** a priest to a height or to a standing position. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I will appoint for myself a faithful priest]

See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of the term that the ULT translates as **faithful**. This could mean: (1) Alternate translation: [an obedient priest]; (2) Alternate translation: [an established priest]

The terms **heart** and **soul** mean similar things, representing in this context inward desires. Yahweh is using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [exactly what I desire for him to do]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And I will establish the house that I build for him]

Yahweh is speaking as if he would construct a physical **house** for this new priest. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And I will make sure that he has a lasting family line]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:30](../02/30.md). Alternate translation: [and he will personally serve my anointed]
Yahweh is using the term **days** to represent time in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [always]

bsb_verse_text: And everyone left in your house will come and bow down to him for a piece of silver or a morsel of bread, pleading, “Please appoint me to some priestly office so that I can eat a piece of bread.”’”
ult_verse_text: And it will happen that every remaining one in your house will come to bow down to him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread, and he will say, “Please assign me to one of the priestly positions to eat a piece of bread.”’”

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הָיָ֗ה כָּל־הַ⁠נּוֹתָר֙ בְּ⁠בֵ֣יתְ⁠ךָ֔ יָבוֹא֙ לְ⁠הִשְׁתַּחֲוֺ֣ת ל֔⁠וֹ לַ⁠אֲג֥וֹרַת כֶּ֖סֶף וְ⁠כִכַּר־לָ֑חֶם וְ⁠אָמַ֗ר סְפָחֵ֥⁠נִי נָ֛א אֶל־אַחַ֥ת הַ⁠כְּהֻנּ֖וֹת לֶ⁠אֱכֹ֥ל פַּת־לָֽחֶם
notes.note: There are three levels of quotation in this verse. The author is continuing to quote the man of God (level 1). The man of God is continuing to tell Eli something that Yahweh has said (level 2). And in the last part of this verse, Yahweh describes what some of the remaining priests will say (level 3). Use the appropriate punctuation in your language to mark these levels of quotation. Alternatively, you could translate this so that there are not three levels of quotation (see the Quotes within Quotes note).

Yahweh is using the term **house** to represent Eli’s family. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in your family]

Bowing down was a symbolic action that expressed submission and indicated need. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [to bow down to him in order to beg him]

Yahweh is using specific small amounts to represent money and food in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [for money and food]
Since Yahweh is referring to a group of people, it might be more natural in your language to use a plural form. Alternate translation: [and they will say]

Yahweh is using one specific thing that people need to do to live, eating **bread**, to mean earning a living in general. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [so that I can earn enough to live on]

bsb_verse_text: And the boy Samuel ministered to the LORD before Eli. Now in those days the word of the LORD was rare, and visions were scarce.
ult_verse_text: Now the boy Samuel was serving Yahweh to the face of Eli. And the word of Yahweh was rare in those days; vision {was} not spread.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הַ⁠נַּ֧עַר שְׁמוּאֵ֛ל מְשָׁרֵ֥ת אֶת־יְהוָ֖ה לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י עֵלִ֑י וּ⁠דְבַר־יְהוָ֗ה הָיָ֤ה יָקָר֙ בַּ⁠יָּמִ֣ים הָ⁠הֵ֔ם אֵ֥ין חָז֖וֹן נִפְרָֽץ
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:11](../02/11.md). Alternate translation: [together with Eli] or [as an apprentice to Eli]

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠דְבַר־יְהוָ֗ה הָיָ֤ה יָקָר֙ בַּ⁠יָּמִ֣ים הָ⁠הֵ֔ם אֵ֥ין חָז֖וֹן נִפְרָֽץ
notes.note: The author may be using two types of revelation, a **word** and a **vision**, to represent revelation in general, which would also include such things as dreams, signs, etc. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Not many people received revelations from Yahweh in those days]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Yahweh said by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And Yahweh rarely spoke to people]

The author is using the term **days** to represent a specific time, since time is made up of days. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [at that time]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Yahweh was not spreading visions]

The author is speaking as if a **vision** were a physical thing that could be **spread**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [not many people had visions]

bsb_verse_text: And at that time Eli, whose eyesight had grown so dim that he could not see, was lying in his room.
ult_verse_text: And it happened in that day that Eli was lying down in his place. Now his eyes had begun {to be} dim; he was not able to see.

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [1:12](../01/12.md).

The author is using the term **day** to represent a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [at that time]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְעֵינָיו֙ הֵחֵ֣לּוּ כֵה֔וֹת לֹ֥א יוּכַ֖ל לִ⁠רְאֽוֹת
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְעֵינָיו֙ הֵחֵ֣לּוּ כֵה֔וֹת לֹ֥א יוּכַ֖ל לִ⁠רְאֽוֹת
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. If it would be clearer in your language, you could combine them. Alternate translation: [Now it had begun to be difficult for him to see well]
The author is using the term **eyes** to represent. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Now his vision]

bsb_verse_text: Before the lamp of God had gone out, Samuel was lying down in the temple of the LORD, where the ark of God was located.
ult_verse_text: And the lamp of God had not yet gone out, and Samuel was lying down in the temple of Yahweh, where the Box of God was there.

notes.note: By **the lamp of God**, the author means the lamp that the law of Moses commanded the Israelites in [Exodus 27:21](../../exo/27/21.md) to keep burning in the tent of meeting all night long. Alternate translation: [And the sacred lamp in the tent of meeting had not yet gone out]

The author is referring to the **lamp** still burning to represent that it was still night, since this lamp only burned at night. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [And it was still night] or [And it was not yet morning]

See the discussion in the Introduction to Chapter 1 of why the author may use the term **temple** here and in [1:9](../01/09.md), and see how you translated the term in [1:9](../01/09.md). Alternate translation: [in the tent of meeting]

It might seem that the expression **there** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [where the Box of God was]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD called to Samuel, and he answered, “Here I am.”
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh called to Samuel. And he said, “Behold me.”

notes.note: Samuel is responding to Yahweh with the courteous expression that a person in this culture would use to tell a superior that he had heard a summons and was ready and willing to obey. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation, here and in [verses 5](../03/05.md), [6](../03/06.md), [8](../03/08.md), and [16](../03/16.md). Alternate translation: [Yes, sir?] or [At your service]

bsb_verse_text: He ran to Eli and said, “Here I am, for you have called me.” “I did not call,” Eli replied. “Go back and lie down.” So he went and lay down.
ult_verse_text: And he ran to Eli and said, “Behold me, for you called to me.” But he said, “I did not call. Go back, lie down.” So he went and lay down.

notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since you called me, I have come to see what I may do for you]

bsb_verse_text: Once again the LORD called, “Samuel!” So Samuel got up, went to Eli, and said, “Here I am, for you have called me.” “My son, I did not call,” Eli replied. “Go back and lie down.”
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh resumed calling Samuel again. And Samuel arose and went to Eli and said, “Behold me, for you called to me.” But he said, “I did not call, my son. Go back, lie down.”

notes.note: Eli is referring to Samuel with an affectionate expression. Use a comparable title or expression from your language and culture for addressing someone affectionately. Alternate translation: [young man]

bsb_verse_text: Now Samuel did not yet know the LORD, because the word of the LORD had not yet been revealed to him.
ult_verse_text: (Now Samuel did not yet know Yahweh, for the word of Yahweh had not yet been revealed to him.)

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠שְׁמוּאֵ֕ל טֶ֖רֶם יָדַ֣ע אֶת־יְהוָ֑ה וְ⁠טֶ֛רֶם יִגָּלֶ֥ה אֵלָ֖י⁠ו דְּבַר־יְהוָֽה
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠שְׁמוּאֵ֕ל טֶ֖רֶם יָדַ֣ע אֶת־יְהוָ֑ה וְ⁠טֶ֛רֶם יִגָּלֶ֥ה אֵלָ֖י⁠ו דְּבַר־יְהוָֽה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because the word of Yahweh had not yet been revealed to Samuel, Samuel did not yet know Yahweh]
The expression **did not … know Yahweh** has a different meaning here than it has in [2:12](../02/12.md). The UST translation of both verses models one way of showing the difference in meaning.

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [for Yahweh had not yet revealed his word to him]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Yahweh would have said by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [for a message from Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Once again, for the third time, the LORD called to Samuel. He got up, went to Eli, and said, “Here I am, for you have called me.” Then Eli realized that it was the LORD who was calling the boy.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh resumed calling Samuel for a third {time}. And he arose and went to Eli and said, “Behold me, for you called to me.” Then Eli understood that Yahweh was calling to the boy.

notes.note: The author is using the adjective **third** as a noun to mean a specific time. The ULT shows this by supplying the word **time**. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [yet again]
If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you can use a cardinal number here or an equivalent expression. Alternate translation: [for time number three]

bsb_verse_text: “Go and lie down,” he said to Samuel, “and if He calls you, say, ‘Speak, LORD, for Your servant is listening.’” So Samuel went and lay down in his place.
ult_verse_text: And Eli said to Samuel, “Go, lie down. And it will happen that, if he calls to you, then you shall say, ‘Speak, Yahweh, for your servant is listening.’” So Samuel went and lay down in his place.

notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since your servant is listening, speak, Yahweh]

This is an imperative, but it communicates a polite request rather than a command. Use a form in your language that communicates a polite request. It may be helpful to add an expression such as “please” to make this clear. Alternate translation: [Please speak]
Samuel is speaking about himself in the third person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could translate this in the first person. Alternate translation: [for I, your servant, am listening]

Samuel assumes that Yahweh will understand that by **listening**, he means he will obey. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [for I will obey]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD came and stood there, calling as before, “Samuel! Samuel!” And Samuel answered, “Speak, for Your servant is listening.”
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh came and stationed himself and called as time upon time, “Samuel, Samuel!” And Samuel said, “Speak, for your servant is listening.”

notes.note: The author is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Yahweh spoke this time just as he had the other times. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [just as he had the previous times]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:9](../03/09.md).

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Samuel, “I am about to do something in Israel at which the ears of all who hear it will tingle.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh said to Samuel, “Behold, I am doing a thing in Israel that everyone hearing it, the two of his ears will tingle.

notes.note: See how you translated the term **Behold** in [2:31](../02/31.md). Alternate translation: [Pay attention!]

Yahweh is speaking in the present tense of something that he is going to do in the near future. He is using that tense in order to show that he will certainly do this. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use the future tense. Alternate translation: [I am going to do]

Yahweh is using a physical sensation that people will have (their **ears** will **tingle**) to represent the emotion that people will feel when they hear this news. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [that will horrify everyone who learns about it]

bsb_verse_text: On that day I will carry out against Eli everything I have spoken about his house, from beginning to end.
ult_verse_text: In that day I will raise up against Eli all of what I have spoken against his house, beginning and ending.

notes.note: The author is using the term **day** to represent a specific time. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [At that time]

Yahweh is speaking as if what he said he would do were something physical that he could **raise up**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will make happen to Eli]

Yahweh is using the term **house** to represent a family, since members of a family often live in the same house. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [his family]

Yahweh is speaking of two things in order to mean them and everything in between. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation: [I will do everything I said]

bsb_verse_text: I told him that I would judge his house forever for the iniquity of which he knows, because his sons blasphemed God and he did not restrain them.
ult_verse_text: Now I have declared to him that I am judging his house forever for the iniquity that he knew. For his sons have been cursing themselves, but he has not restrained them.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הִגַּ֣דְתִּי ל֔⁠וֹ כִּֽי־שֹׁפֵ֥ט אֲנִ֛י אֶת־בֵּית֖⁠וֹ עַד־עוֹלָ֑ם בַּ⁠עֲוֺ֣ן אֲשֶׁר־יָדַ֗ע כִּֽי־מְקַֽלְלִ֤ים לָ⁠הֶם֙ בָּנָ֔י⁠ו וְ⁠לֹ֥א כִהָ֖ה בָּֽ⁠ם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because Eli’s sons have been cursing themselves and he has not restrained them, I have told him that I am judging his house forever for the iniquity that he knew]

Yahweh is providing background information to help Samuel understand why he is judging and punishing Eli’s family. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

Yahweh is speaking in the present tense of something that he is going to do in the near future. He is using that tense in order to show that he will certainly do it. If it would be clearer in your language, you could use the future tense. Alternate translation: [I am about to judge]
See how you translated the term **house** in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [his family]

The sense of the reflexive form here is not that Eli’s sons have actually spoken curses against themselves. Rather, Yahweh means that their actions have been so bad that these sons deserve to be cursed. Alternate translation: [have been making themselves accursed] or [have caused me to curse them]

bsb_verse_text: Therefore I have sworn to the house of Eli, ‘The iniquity of Eli’s house shall never be atoned for by sacrifice or offering.’”
ult_verse_text: And therefore I have sworn to the house of Eli, ‘If forever the iniquity of the house of Eli will cover itself by sacrifice or by offering!’”

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [3:12](../03/12.md). Alternate translation: [to the family of Eli]

notes.orig_language_quote: אִֽם־יִתְכַּפֵּ֞ר עֲוֺ֧ן בֵּית־עֵלִ֛י בְּ⁠זֶ֥בַח וּ⁠בְ⁠מִנְחָ֖ה עַד־עוֹלָֽם
notes.note: Following the custom of this culture, Yahweh is swearing an oath by stating the first part of a condition (“if”) but not the second part (“then”). The implication is that if the first part of the condition were met, something very bad would happen, so it is certain that the first part of the condition will not be met. You could indicate that meaning in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [The iniquity of the house of Eli will certainly never cover itself by sacrifice or by offering]

notes.orig_language_quote: אִֽם־יִתְכַּפֵּ֞ר עֲוֺ֧ן בֵּית־עֵלִ֛י בְּ⁠זֶ֥בַח וּ⁠בְ⁠מִנְחָ֖ה עַד־עוֹלָֽם
notes.note: Yahweh is speaking as if **iniquity** were a living thing that could **cover itself**. He is using the idea of covering to represent atonement for sin. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Neither sacrifice nor offering will ever cover the iniquity of the house of Eli] or [No one will ever be able to make atonement for the iniquity of the house of Eli]

bsb_verse_text: Samuel lay down until the morning; then he opened the doors of the house of the LORD. He was afraid to tell Eli the vision,
ult_verse_text: And Samuel lay until the morning, then he opened the doors of the house of Yahweh. But Samuel was afraid of telling the vision to Eli.

notes.note: The author is using one specific action that Samuel performed, opening these **doors**, to represent all of his regular duties. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then he went about his duties as usual]
See the discussion of these **doors** in the Introduction to this chapter.

The author assumes that readers will understand that Samuel did not tell Eli about the vision because he was afraid to do so. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [But Samuel was afraid of telling the vision to Eli, so he did not tell him]

By **the vision**, the author seems to be implying that Yahweh appeared visibly to Samuel when he came and said the things he records in [3:11–14](../03/11.md). The author’s statement in [3:10](../03/10.md) that Yahweh “came and stationed himself” next to Samuel suggests that this was the case. Alternate translation: [what he had seen and heard]

bsb_verse_text: but Eli called to him and said, “Samuel, my son.” “Here I am,” answered Samuel.
ult_verse_text: But Eli called Samuel and said, “Samuel, my son.” And he said, “Behold me.”

notes.note: See how you translated this affectionate expression in [3:6](../03/06.md). Alternate translation: [young man]

bsb_verse_text: “What was the message He gave you?” Eli asked. “Do not hide it from me. May God punish you, and ever so severely, if you hide from me anything He said to you.”
ult_verse_text: And he said, “What {was} the word that he spoke to you? Please do not hide {it} from me. Thus may God do to you, and thus may he add, if you hide from me a word from all of the word that he spoke to you.”

notes.note: Eli is using the term **word** to represent what Yahweh said by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [was the message]
If it would be clearer in your language, you could express this negative request as a positive one. Alternate translation: [Please show it to me]

Eli is speaking as if information were a physical object that Samuel might **hide**. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Please do not withhold it from me]

notes.orig_language_quote: כֹּ֣ה יַעֲשֶׂה־לְּ⁠ךָ֤ אֱלֹהִים֙ וְ⁠כֹ֣ה יוֹסִ֔יף אִם־תְּכַחֵ֤ד מִמֶּ֨⁠נִּי֙ דָּבָ֔ר מִ⁠כָּל־הַ⁠דָּבָ֖ר אֲשֶׁר־דִּבֶּ֥ר אֵלֶֽי⁠ךָ
notes.note: Eli is swearing an oath. Following the custom of his culture, he is asking God to do to Samuel the things God said he would do to Eli and his family if Samuel does not answer him truthfully. Use a natural way in your language to express an oath.

Eli is using a common expression of his culture to emphasize that he wants Samuel to tell him everything. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and even more]

Eli is making an overstatement for emphasis. By saying that he does not want Samuel to leave out a single word of what Yahweh said, he means that he wants Samuel to tell him all of the content of what Yahweh said. Alternate translation: [anything]

Eli is using the term **word** in the second instance in the verse to represent what Yahweh said by using words. In your translation, in both instances you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [from the entire message]

bsb_verse_text: So Samuel told him everything and did not hide a thing from him. “He is the LORD,” replied Eli. “Let Him do what is good in His eyes.”
ult_verse_text: So Samuel declared to him all of the words, and he did not hide {anything} from him. And he said, “It {is} Yahweh. May he do the good in his eyes.”

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יַּגֶּד־ל֤⁠וֹ שְׁמוּאֵל֙ אֶת־כָּל־הַ⁠דְּבָרִ֔ים וְ⁠לֹ֥א כִחֵ֖ד מִמֶּ֑⁠נּוּ
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. If it would be clearer in your language, you could combine them. Alternate translation: [So Samuel openly told Eli everything that Yahweh had said]
See how you translated the similar expression in [3:17](../03/17.md). Alternate translation: [the whole message]
The pronoun **he** refers to Eli. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And Eli said]

Eli is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [It is Yahweh who has said this, and I acknowledge his authority to judge and punish my family]

Eli is using the adjective **good** as a noun. Your language may use adjectives in the same way. If not, you can translate this adjective with an equivalent phrase. Alternate translation: [what is good]
See how you translated this similar expression in [1:18](../01/18.md). Alternate translation: [in his judgment]

bsb_verse_text: And Samuel grew, and the LORD was with him, and He let none of Samuel’s words fall to the ground.
ult_verse_text: And Samuel grew, and Yahweh was with him, and he did not cause {anything} from all of his words to fall to the ground.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּגְדַּ֖ל שְׁמוּאֵ֑ל וַֽ⁠יהוָה֙ הָיָ֣ה עִמּ֔⁠וֹ וְ⁠לֹֽא־הִפִּ֥יל מִ⁠כָּל־דְּבָרָ֖י⁠ו אָֽרְצָ⁠ה
notes.note: Here and in the next two verses, the author is describing what happened at the end of the story of Samuel coming to know Yahweh. Your language may have its own way of presenting such information.

The author is using a common expression of his culture to mean that Yahweh helped Samuel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation, as in the UST: [and Yahweh helped him]

The author is speaking as if **words** were physical objects that could **fall to the ground**. The suggestion is that Samuel’s words were never lost or ruined as things do that people drop or let fall, in other words, what he said always came true. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he made sure that everything Samuel said came true]

The author is using the term **words** to represent what Samuel said by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [everything he said]

bsb_verse_text: So all Israel from Dan to Beersheba knew that Samuel was confirmed as a prophet of the LORD.
ult_verse_text: So all of Israel, from Dan and unto Beersheba, knew that Samuel was established as a prophet of Yahweh.

notes.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to 1 Samuel of the use of the name of an ancestor to mean his descendants, and see how you translated this usage in [1:17](../01/17.md). Alternate translation: [the Israelites]

The author is speaking of two cities at the opposite ends of Israel’s territory in order to mean them and all the territory in between them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [across its entire territory]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Yahweh had established Samuel as his prophet]

See the discussion in the Introduction to Chapter 2 of the term that the ULT translates as “faithful” in [2:35](../02/35.md). That term could have the same meaning here. Alternate translation: [was faithful]

bsb_verse_text: And the LORD continued to appear at Shiloh, because there He revealed Himself to Samuel by His word.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh continued to appear in Shiloh. For Yahweh revealed himself to Samuel in Shiloh by the word of Yahweh.

notes.note: Here the word **For** introduces an explanation rather than a reason. Alternate translation: [This happened as]

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Yahweh said by using words. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [as he spoke to him]

bsb_verse_text: Thus the word of Samuel came to all Israel. Now the Israelites went out to meet the Philistines in battle and camped at Ebenezer, while the Philistines camped at Aphek.
ult_verse_text: And the word of Samuel was to all of Israel.

notes.note: See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of how you might format this sentence to show that it is part of the author’s conclusion in [3:19–21](../03/19.md) of the story of how Samuel became a prophet.

The author is using the term **word** to represent what Samuel said by using words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And Samuel spoke messages to all Israel]

See the discussion in the Introduction to 1 Samuel of the use of the name of an ancestor to mean his descendants, and see how you translated this usage in [1:17](../01/17.md). Alternate translation: [the Israelites. Now the Israelites went out]

bsb_verse_text: The Philistines arrayed themselves against Israel, and as the battle spread, Israel was defeated by the Philistines, who struck down about four thousand men on the battlefield.
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines arrayed to meet Israel, and the battle spread, and Israel was struck to the face of the Philistines. And they struck in the array in the field about 4, 000 men.

notes.note: See the discussion of the term **face** in the Introduction to 1 Samuel, and see how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [and Israel was struck by the Philistines]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and the Philistines struck the Israelites]

The word translated **was struck** here, meaning “was defeated,” is different from the one in the next sentence translated **they struck**, meaning “they killed.” Alternate translation: [and Israel was defeated by the Philistines] or [and the Philistines defeated the Israelites]
The pronoun **they** refers to the Philistine soldiers. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines struck]
See the discussion of the term **struck** in the Introduction to 1 Samuel. Alternate translation: [And they killed]

bsb_verse_text: When the troops returned to the camp, the elders of Israel asked, “Why has the LORD brought defeat on us before the Philistines today? Let us bring the ark of the covenant of the LORD from Shiloh, so that it may go with us to save us from the hand of our enemies.”
ult_verse_text: And the people came into the camp, and the elders of Israel said, “Why did Yahweh strike us today to the face of the Philistines? Let us take for ourselves from Shiloh the Box of the Covenant of Yahweh, and it will come in our midst, and it will save us from the palm of our enemies.”

notes.orig_language_quote: לָ֣⁠מָּה נְגָפָ֧⁠נוּ יְהוָ֛ה הַ⁠יּ֖וֹם לִ⁠פְנֵ֣י פְלִשְׁתִּ֑ים
notes.note: There is an implicit answer to this question in what the elders decide to do the rest of this verse. They feel as if Yahweh himself has defeated them, and they believe the reason is that they did not bring the Box of the Covenant with them into battle. See the discussion in the Introduction to this chapter of why they believed this. The UST models one way to supply this implicit information.

See the discussion in the Introduction to 1 Samuel of the use of the word “hand” to represent power. The elders are using the word **palm** here to mean the same thing. Alternate translation: [from the power of our enemies]

bsb_verse_text: So the people sent men to Shiloh, and they brought back the ark of the covenant of the LORD of Hosts, who sits enthroned between the cherubim. And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were there with the ark of the covenant of God.
ult_verse_text: So the people sent to Shiloh, and they carried from there the Box of the Covenant of Yahweh of Armies, sitter on the cherubim. And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, {were} there with the Box of the Covenant of God.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠שָׁ֞ם שְׁנֵ֣י בְנֵֽי־עֵלִ֗י עִם & חָפְנִ֖י וּ⁠פִֽינְחָֽס
notes.note: The word **there** does not refer to Shiloh but to the place to which the Israelites brought the **Box of the Covenant**. Alternate translation: [And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, were accompanying]

bsb_verse_text: When the ark of the covenant of the LORD entered the camp, all the Israelites raised such a great shout that the ground shook.
ult_verse_text: And it happened at the coming of the Box of the Covenant of Yahweh into the camp that all of Israel shouted a great shout, and the earth resounded.

notes.note: See how you translated the phrase “And it happened” in [1:12](../01/12.md).

For emphasis, the author is using a construction in which a verb and its object come from the same root. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of showing the emphasis. Alternate translation: [that all of Israel shouted very loudly]

bsb_verse_text: On hearing the noise of the shout, the Philistines asked, “What is this loud shouting in the camp of the Hebrews?” And when they realized that the ark of the LORD had entered the camp,
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines heard the sound of the shout, and they said, “What {is} the sound of this great shout in the camp of the Hebrews?” Then they learned that the Box of Yahweh had come into the camp.

notes.note: It might seem that the expression **the sound of the shout** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [the shout]

The author is speaking of **the Box of Yahweh** as if it were a living thing that could have **come into the camp** on its own. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the Israelites had brought the Box of God into their camp]

bsb_verse_text: the Philistines were afraid. “The gods have entered their camp!” they said. “Woe to us, for nothing like this has happened before.
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines feared, for they said, “A god has come into the camp!” And they said, “Woe to us! For it was not like this yesterday {or} the third day!

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יִּֽרְאוּ֙ הַ⁠פְּלִשְׁתִּ֔ים כִּ֣י אָמְר֔וּ בָּ֥א אֱלֹהִ֖ים אֶל־הַֽ⁠מַּחֲנֶ֑ה
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines said, “A god has come into the camp!” and that thought made them very afraid]

The word that the ULT translates as **god** is plural, but the verb **has come** is singular. This suggests that as the author expresses the meaning of what the Philistines said in their own language, he is using the plural form to indicate greatness. Your language may be able to use a plural subject with a singular verb for this same purpose. If not, you could convey the meaning in another way. Alternate translation: [A great god has come into the camp]

The Philistines are using a phrase that expresses a strong feeling, fear. There may be an equivalent word or phrase in your language that you can use in your translation to convey this strong feeling. If not, you could say what the Philistines were feeling, or you could say what they were afraid of, here and in the next verse. Alternate translation: [Oh, no!] or [We are in great danger!]

In this culture, the current day was considered the first day, the previous day was considered the second day, and the day before that was considered **the third day**. In your translation, describe these days as your language and culture naturally would. Alternate translation: [yesterday or the day before]

The Philistines are using **yesterday or the third day** as a common expression of their culture to mean “at any time in the past.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in days gone by] or [ever in the past]

bsb_verse_text: Woe to us! Who will deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? These are the gods who struck the Egyptians with all kinds of plagues in the wilderness.
ult_verse_text: Woe to us! Who will deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods? These are they, the gods having struck the Egyptians with every plague in the wilderness.

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ֣י יַצִּילֵ֔⁠נוּ מִ⁠יַּ֛ד הָ⁠אֱלֹהִ֥ים הָ⁠אַדִּירִ֖ים הָ⁠אֵ֑לֶּה
notes.note: The Philistines are using the question form for emphasis. If a speaker of your language would not use the question form for that purpose, you could translate this as a statement or as an exclamation. Alternate translation: [We cannot imagine who could deliver us from the hand of these mighty gods!]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [from the power of]

The word **gods** is plural in both instances, and the verb **struck** is also plural. This suggests that the author is showing that the Philistines were speaking here about multiple gods whom they mistakenly thought the Israelites worshiped. The Philistines apparently thought that one of these gods had come into the Israelite camp when the Box of the Covenant arrived. So it would be appropriate to use plural forms in your translation.

It might seem that the expression **These are they, the gods who struck** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [These are the same gods who struck]

The Philistine soldiers are speaking as if Yahweh had actually **struck** or hit the Egyptians with these plagues. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [who afflicted]

The Philistines are making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [with many terrible plagues]
See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to this chapter.

bsb_verse_text: Take courage and be men, O Philistines! Otherwise, you will serve the Hebrews just as they served you. Now be men and fight!”
ult_verse_text: Strengthen yourselves and be men, Philistines, lest you serve for the Hebrews, just as they have served for you. So be men and fight!”

notes.orig_language_quote: הִֽתְחַזְּק֞וּ וִֽ⁠הְי֤וּ לַֽ⁠אֲנָשִׁים֙ פְּלִשְׁתִּ֔ים פֶּ֚ן תַּעַבְד֣וּ לָ⁠עִבְרִ֔ים כַּ⁠אֲשֶׁ֥ר עָבְד֖וּ לָ⁠כֶ֑ם
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [So that you do not serve for the Hebrews, just as they have served for you, strengthen yourselves and be men, Philistines]

The Philistines are using the term **men** to represent people who are courageous. The implication is that strong, experienced, full-grown men would be courageous in situations where weaker, inexperienced boys and youths would not. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [Strengthen yourselves and be courageous]

These two phrases mean similar things. The Philistines are using the two terms together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [Be very courageous]

The phrase **be men and fight** expresses a single idea. The word **fight** tells more about what **men** would or should do in this situation. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this meaning in a different way. Alternate translation: [So fight courageously]

bsb_verse_text: So the Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, and each man fled to his tent. The slaughter was very great—thirty thousand foot soldiers of Israel fell.
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines fought, and Israel was struck and fled, a man to his tent. And it was a very great striking, for 30, 000 foot soldiers from Israel fell.

notes.note: The author assumes that readers will know that by **fought**, he means that the Philistines fought courageously, as they told themselves they had to do. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [So the Philistines fought courageously]

The author is using **a man to his tent** as a common expression of his culture to mean that the soldiers stopped their military campaign altogether and each of them went back to his home and family. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and they defeated the Israelite soldiers, who fled from the battle and left the army and went home]

The word **striking** here is from the same root word as the verb that the ULT translates as “struck” in [4:2](../04/02.md). See how you translated the verb there. Alternate translation: [a very great slaughter]

The author is using the term **fell** to mean that these soldiers were killed in the battle, to represent the way they fell to the ground when they died. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [for 30,000 foot soldiers from Israel died]

bsb_verse_text: The ark of God was captured, and Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, died.
ult_verse_text: And the Box of God was taken, and the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Phinehas, died.

notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And the Philistines took the Box of God]

bsb_verse_text: That same day a Benjamite ran from the battle line all the way to Shiloh, with his clothes torn and dirt on his head.
ult_verse_text: And a man of Benjamin ran from the array and entered Shiloh on that day. And his clothes were torn, and earth was on his head.

notes.note: Tearing his **clothes** and putting **earth** on his **head** were symbolic actions by which this man demonstrated his great distress over the news he was bringing. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [And he had torn his clothes and put earth on his head to show his great distress]

bsb_verse_text: When he arrived, there was Eli, sitting on his chair beside the road and watching, because his heart trembled for the ark of God. When the man entered the city to give a report, the whole city cried out.
ult_verse_text: And he came, and behold, Eli was sitting on a seat at the side of the road, watching, for his heart {was} afraid concerning the Box of God. And the man came into the city to report, and all of the city cried out.

notes.note: The author is using the term **behold** to call attention to what he is about to say. See how you translated the similar expression in [2:31](../02/31.md), where Yahweh uses the term in the same way.

Since the author explains in [4:15](../04/15.md) that Eli was blind, he does not mean that Eli was literally **watching** the road to see whether any messengers were coming. He means that Eli was waiting for news and hoping to recognize a messenger from the sound of his arrival. Alternate translation: [waiting]

The author is using one part of Eli, his **heart**, to mean all of him in the act of feeling strongly. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he was greatly afraid]

The author is using the term **city** to represent the people of the city. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and all of the people of the city cried out]

The author is making an overstatement for emphasis. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express the emphasis in a different way. Alternate translation: [and people throughout the city cried out]

bsb_verse_text: Eli heard the outcry and asked, “Why this commotion?” So the man hurried over and reported to Eli.
ult_verse_text: And Eli heard the sound of the outcry, and he said, “What {is} the sound of this tumult?” And the man hurried and came and reported to Eli.

notes.note: It might seem that this expression contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [the outcry]
This phrase expresses a single idea by using two words connected with **and**. The word **hurried** tells in what way the messenger **came**. Alternate translation: [came hurriedly]

bsb_verse_text: Now Eli was ninety-eight years old, and his gaze was fixed because he could not see.
ult_verse_text: Now Eli {was} a son of 98 years. And his eyes had set, and he was not able to see.

notes.note: The author is using a common expression of his culture to state someone’s age. In your translation, express this in the way your culture would state someone’s age. Alternate translation, as in the UST: [was 98 years old]

The author is using the phrase **his eyes had set** to describe an eye condition that was most likely cataracts. He said of Eli in [3:2](../03/02.md) that “his eyes had begun to be dim,” that is, he could see objects only faintly. Now the cataracts had advanced to the point where his eyes no longer moved. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could name this condition explicitly in your translation. Alternate translation: [And he had severe cataracts, so he was not able to see anything]

bsb_verse_text: “I have just come from the battle,” the man said to Eli. “I fled from there today.” “What happened, my son?” Eli asked.
ult_verse_text: And the man said to Eli, “I {am} the one coming from the array, and I myself fled from the array today.” And he said, “What was the event, my son?”

notes.orig_language_quote: אָֽנֹכִי֙ הַ⁠בָּ֣א מִן־הַ⁠מַּעֲרָכָ֔ה וַ⁠אֲנִ֕י מִן־הַ⁠מַּעֲרָכָ֖ה נַ֣סְתִּי הַ⁠יּ֑וֹם
notes.note: The messenger is using poetic language to introduce the solemn news that he must share. Following the conventions of Hebrew poetry, he is saying something and then repeating the idea in different words. It may be helpful in your translation to connect these phrases with a word other than **and** to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [I have just come from the battle lines, indeed, I myself fled from them today]

Eli is addressing the messenger with a polite and gentle expression. Use a comparable title or expression for addressing someone politely and gently in your language. Alternate translation: [young man]

bsb_verse_text: The messenger answered, “Israel has fled before the Philistines, and there has been a great slaughter among the people. Your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are both dead, and the ark of God has been captured.”
ult_verse_text: And the one bringing news answered and said, “Israel fled to the face of the Philistines. And also a great slaughter has been among the people. And also the two of your sons, Hophni and Phinehas, have died, and the Box of God has been taken.”

notes.note: The expression **and said** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this expression explicitly. Alternate translation: [And the one bringing news replied]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and the Philistines have taken the Box of God]

bsb_verse_text: As soon as the ark of God was mentioned, Eli fell backward from his chair by the city gate, and being old and heavy, he broke his neck and died. And Eli had judged Israel forty years.
ult_verse_text: And it happened, in his mentioning of the Box of God, that he fell backward from upon the seat at the side of the gate. And his neck was broken, and he died, for the man {was} old and heavy. And he had judged Israel 40 years.

notes.note: The pronoun **his** refers to the messenger, while the pronoun **he** refers to Eli. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [when the messenger mentioned the Box of God, that Eli fell backward]

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תִּשָּׁבֵ֤ר מַפְרַקְתּ⁠וֹ֙ וַ⁠יָּמֹ֔ת כִּֽי־זָקֵ֥ן הָ⁠אִ֖ישׁ וְ⁠כָבֵ֑ד
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And since the man was old and heavy, his neck was broken, and he died]
If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And he broke his neck]
Here the author is presenting information that concludes the story of the life of Eli. This is the last mention of Eli in the book. Your language may have its own way of presenting such information.

bsb_verse_text: Now Eli’s daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, was pregnant and about to give birth. When she heard the news of the capture of God’s ark and the deaths of her father-in-law and her husband, she collapsed and gave birth, for her labor pains overtook her.
ult_verse_text: Now his daughter-in-law, the wife of Phinehas, {was} pregnant, {about} to give birth. And she heard the report about the Box of God being taken and {that} her father-in-law had died and her husband. And she knelt down and gave birth, for her pangs turned themselves upon her.

notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [that the Philistines had taken the Box of God]
It may be more natural in your language and culture to put the information about **her husband** before the information about **her father-in-law** as in the UST.

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [And her pangs turned themselves upon her, so she knelt down and gave birth]

The author is using a common expression of his culture to describe childbirth. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation. Alternate translation: [she abruptly went into labor]

bsb_verse_text: As she was dying, the women attending to her said, “Do not be afraid, for you have given birth to a son!” But she did not respond or pay any heed.
ult_verse_text: And about the time of her dying, then the ones standing over her said, “Do not fear, for you have borne a son.” But she did not answer, for she did not set her heart.

notes.note: The author assumes that readers will understand that because this childbirth was provoked by great grief and distress, it was very difficult, and it caused the death of the mother. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And unfortunately her delivery was so difficult that it would cause her to die, but as she was dying]

In the original language, the verbs **standing** and **said** are marked as feminine, indicating that this is a reference to women who were helping Phinehas’ wife deliver her baby. If your language does not mark verbs for gender, you may wish to indicate this explicitly in your translation. Alternate translation: [then the women standing over her said]

The author is using the phrase **standing over her** by association to refer to the women who were helping Phinehas’ wife deliver her baby. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the women who were helping her deliver her baby]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since you have borne a son, do not fear]

Here the **heart** represents the thoughts and feelings. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [But she did not answer, and she paid no attention to this]

If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [But since she did not set her heart, she did not answer] or [But she paid no attention to this, so she did not answer]

bsb_verse_text: And she named the boy Ichabod, saying, “The glory has departed from Israel,” because the ark of God had been captured and her father-in-law and her husband had been killed.
ult_verse_text: And she called the boy Ichabod, saying, “The glory has departed from Israel,” about the Box of God being taken and about her father-in-law and her husband.

notes.note: The name Ichabod means “no glory.” If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain this in a footnote.
See the discussion of the term **saying** in the Introduction to 1 Samuel. It may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly.

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [about the Philistines taking of the Box of God]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and about the deaths of her father-in-law and her husband]
See how you translated the similar expression in [4:19](../04/19.md). Alternate translation: [and about her husband and her father-in-law]

bsb_verse_text: “The glory has departed from Israel,” she said, “for the ark of God has been captured.”
ult_verse_text: Now she said “the glory has departed from Israel” because the Box of God had been taken.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תֹּ֕אמֶר גָּלָ֥ה כָב֖וֹד מִ⁠יִּשְׂרָאֵ֑ל כִּ֥י נִלְקַ֖ח אֲר֥וֹן הָ⁠אֱלֹהִֽים
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand more specifically what has happened in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠תֹּ֕אמֶר גָּלָ֥ה כָב֖וֹד מִ⁠יִּשְׂרָאֵ֑ל כִּ֥י נִלְקַ֖ח אֲר֥וֹן הָ⁠אֱלֹהִֽים
notes.note: The quotation from Phinehas’s wife may extend to the end of the verse. Alternate translation: [And she said, “The glory has departed from Israel, for the Box of God had been taken!”]

If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [the Philistines had taken the Box of God]

bsb_verse_text: After the Philistines had captured the ark of God, they took it from Ebenezer to Ashdod,
ult_verse_text: Now the Philistines had taken the Box of God and brought it from Ebenezer to Ashdod.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠פְלִשְׁתִּים֙ לָֽקְח֔וּ אֵ֖ת אֲר֣וֹן הָ⁠אֱלֹהִ֑ים וַ⁠יְבִאֻ֛⁠הוּ מֵ⁠אֶ֥בֶן הָעֵ֖זֶר אַשְׁדּֽוֹדָ⁠ה
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand what happens next in the story. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.

bsb_verse_text: carried it into the temple of Dagon, and set it beside his statue.
ult_verse_text: And the Philistines took the Box of God and caused it to enter the house of Dagon. And they placed it beside Dagon.

notes.note: The author is speaking as if Dagon’s temple were a **house** in which he lived. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the temple of Dagon]
The word **Dagon** is the name of a false god that the Philistines worshiped.

Placing the Box of Yahweh **beside Dagon** in his temple was a symbolic action by which the Philistines were asserting that Dagon had defeated Yahweh and thus his people, the Israelites. They were treating the Box of God as a trophy of victory. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [And they placed it beside Dagon to suggest that Dagon had defeated Yahweh]

The assumes that readers will know that by **Dagon**, he means the large statue of Dagon that was in the temple at Ashdod. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the large statue of Dagon in the temple]

bsb_verse_text: When the people of Ashdod got up early the next morning, there was Dagon, fallen on his face before the ark of the LORD. So they took Dagon and returned him to his place.
ult_verse_text: And the Ashdodites arose early on the next day, and behold, Dagon was fallen on his face to the ground to the face of the Box of Yahweh. And they took Dagon and returned him to his place.

notes.note: Here the expression **arose early** does not necessarily mean that the Ashdodites got up earlier than usual in order to look inside the temple. While the author often does use the expression to mean that people got up earlier than usual in order to do an action he describes, for example, in [1:19](../01/19.md) and [15:12](../15/12.md), here and in the next verse it introduces what happened when the Ashdodites first got up. The UST models one way to express this meaning.
See how you translated the word “Behold” in [2:31](../02/31.md). Alternate translation: [and they found that Dagon]

In this culture, lying face down on the ground in front of someone was an action that symbolized submission. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [Dagon was submissively lying prostrate]
See how you translated the similar expression in [1:12](../01/12.md). Alternate translation: [before]

bsb_verse_text: But when they got up early the next morning, there was Dagon, fallen on his face before the ark of the LORD, with his head and his hands broken off and lying on the threshold. Only the torso remained.
ult_verse_text: And they arose early in the morning on the next day, and behold, Dagon had fallen on his face to the ground to the face of the Box of Yahweh. And the head of Dagon and the two of the palms of his hands were cut off, on the threshold. Only Dagon was left on him.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠רֹ֨אשׁ דָּג֜וֹן וּ⁠שְׁתֵּ֣י ׀ כַּפּ֣וֹת יָדָ֗י⁠ו כְּרֻתוֹת֙
notes.note: If your language does not use this passive form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And it appeared that someone had cut off the head of Dagon and the two of the palms of his hands]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠רֹ֨אשׁ דָּג֜וֹן וּ⁠שְׁתֵּ֣י ׀ כַּפּ֣וֹת יָדָ֗י⁠ו כְּרֻתוֹת֙
notes.note: Cutting off the **head** and **hands** of Dagon was a symbolic action that indicated that this false god was not wise enough or strong enough to defend himself. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. Alternate translation: [And the head of Dagon and the two of the palms of his hands were cut off, demonstrating how helpless he actually was]

The word that the ULT translates as **hands** could indicate someone’s entire lower arms, so the author is clarifying what specific part of them had been **cut off**. Your language may be able to refer to this part more simply, and so this expression may seem to contain extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [and his hands]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and they were lying on the threshold]

Leaving the **head** and **hands** of Dagon on the **threshold**, where people coming in and out of the temple would trample on them, was a symbolic action that expressed contempt for these symbols of Dagon’s supposed wisdom and power. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation: [Someone had left them contemptuously on the threshold]

The author assumes that his readers will understand that by **Dagon**, in this instance he means the part of the statute that looked like a fish. The name Dagon comes from the word for “fish.” Fish symbolized prosperity for the Philistines, who lived by the seacoast. Statues of Dagon had a human head and hands but the body of a fish. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [The only thing left of the statute was the part that looked like a fish]

bsb_verse_text: That is why, to this day, the priests of Dagon and all who enter the temple of Dagon in Ashdod do not step on the threshold.
ult_verse_text: (Therefore the priests of Dagon and all of the ones entering the house of Dagon do not tread on the threshold of Dagon in Ashdod to this day.)

notes.orig_language_quote: עַל־כֵּ֡ן לֹֽא־יִדְרְכוּ֩ כֹהֲנֵ֨י דָג֜וֹן וְ⁠כָֽל־הַ⁠בָּאִ֧ים בֵּית־דָּג֛וֹן עַל־מִפְתַּ֥ן דָּג֖וֹן בְּ⁠אַשְׁדּ֑וֹד עַ֖ד הַ⁠יּ֥וֹם הַ⁠זֶּֽה
notes.note: The author is providing background information to help readers understand how what happened in this story is the source of a cultural practice with which they may be familiar. In your translation, introduce this information in a way that would be natural in your own language and culture.
See how you translated the similar expression in [5:2](../05/02.md).

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [the threshold of the temple of Dagon]

See the discussion of this phrase in the Introduction to 1 Samuel. The author is using this phrase to refer to the time when he was writing. In your translation, make clear that the phrase refers to a time that is now in the past. Avoid giving the impression the phrase means “to the present day.” Alternate translation: [right up to the time of this writing]

bsb_verse_text: Now the hand of the LORD was heavy on the people of Ashdod and its vicinity, ravaging them and afflicting them with tumors.
ult_verse_text: And the hand of Yahweh was heavy on the Ashdodites, and he devastated them and struck them with tumors, Ashdod and its borders.

notes.note: See the discussion of the term **hand** in the Introduction to 1 Samuel, and see how you translated the term in [4:8](../04/08.md). Alternate translation: [And Yahweh used his power greatly against the Ashdodites]

This seems to be an implicit reference to a plague that **devastated** the crops in the area. The description of the guilt offering in [6:4](../06/04.md) indicates that this was a plague of mice that came in great numbers and devoured the crops. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and he sent a plague of mice that devoured their crops]

The word **tumors** refers to some kind of skin growth. The author distinguishes in [5:9](../05/09.md) and [5:12](../05/12.md) between people who were struck with this affliction and people who died, indicating that it was not immediately fatal. It could mean: (1) tumors, as in the ULT. (2) hemorrhoids. Alternate translation: [and struck them with hemorrhoids]

The author is using the name **Ashdod** to represent the people who lived in that city, and he is using the term **borders** to represent “territories,” since territories may be defined by their borders. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the people of Ashdod and the surrounding territories]

bsb_verse_text: And when the men of Ashdod saw what was happening, they said, “The ark of the God of Israel must not stay here with us, because His hand is heavy upon us and upon our god Dagon.”
ult_verse_text: And the men of Ashdod saw that {it was} thus, and they said, “The Box of the God of Israel should not stay with us, for his hand is severe against us and against Dagon our god.”

notes.note: Here the masculine term **men** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [And the people of Ashdod saw]

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹֽא־יֵשֵׁ֞ב אֲר֨וֹן אֱלֹהֵ֤י יִשְׂרָאֵל֙ עִמָּ֔⁠נוּ כִּֽי־קָשְׁתָ֤ה יָד⁠וֹ֙ עָלֵ֔י⁠נוּ וְ⁠עַ֖ל דָּג֥וֹן אֱלֹהֵֽי⁠נוּ
notes.note: If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Since the hand of the God of Israel is severe against us and against Dagon our god, his Box should not stay with us]
See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [for he is using his power greatly]

bsb_verse_text: So they called together all the rulers of the Philistines and asked, “What shall we do with the ark of the God of Israel?” “It must be moved to Gath,” they replied. So they carried away the ark of the God of Israel.
ult_verse_text: So they sent and gathered all of the lords of the Philistines to them, and they said, “What shall we do with the Box of the God of Israel?” And they said, “Let the Box of the God of Israel go around {to} Gath.” So they brought around the Box of the God of Israel.

notes.note: The people of Ashdod are speaking of **the Box of the God of Israel** as if it were a living thing that could **go around to Gath** by itself. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Have someone bring the Box of the God of Israel over to Gath]

It might seem that the expression **brought around** contains extra information that would not be natural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. Alternate translation: [So they brought the Box of the God of Israel]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [So they brought the Box of the God of Israel to Gath]

bsb_verse_text: But after they had moved the ark to Gath, the LORD’s hand was also against that city, throwing it into great confusion and afflicting the men of the city, both young and old, with an outbreak of tumors.
ult_verse_text: And it happened after they brought it around that the hand of Yahweh was on the city, a very great tumult. And he struck the men of the city from small and unto great. And tumors broke out on them.

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [1:12](../01/12.md).
See how you translated the similar expression in [5:6](../05/06.md). Alternate translation: [that Yahweh also used his power against that city]

The author is leaving out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You can supply these words from the context if that would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [and this caused a very great tumult]
See the discussion of the term **struck** in the Introduction to 1 Samuel, and see how you translated the term in [4:2](../04/02.md). Alternate translation: [And he killed]

Here the masculine term **men** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. Alternate translation: [the people of the city]

The author is speaking of two groups of people in order to mean them and everyone in between. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Here the words **small** and **great** could mean either “young” and “old” or “weak” and “powerful,” but the meaning would be basically the same either way. Alternate translation: [regardless of their social condition]

The pronoun **them** refers not to the **men** whom Yahweh **struck** but to other people in the city of Gath. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [on others of them] or [on other people in the city]

bsb_verse_text: So they sent the ark of God to Ekron, but as it arrived, the Ekronites cried out, “They have brought us the ark of the God of Israel in order to kill us and our people!”
ult_verse_text: So they sent the Box of God {to} Ekron. And it happened as the Box of God entered Ekron that the Ekronites cried out, saying, “They have brought around to me the Box of the God of Israel to kill me and my people!”

notes.note: The pronoun **they** refers to the people of Gath. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [So the people of Gath sent]
See whether you chose to represent the term **saying** in [4:21](../04/21.md), and if so, how you translated it.

notes.orig_language_quote: הֵסַ֤בּוּ אֵלַ⁠י֙ אֶת־אֲרוֹן֙ אֱלֹהֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל לַ⁠הֲמִיתֵ֖⁠נִי וְ⁠אֶת־עַמִּֽ⁠י
notes.note: The author is describing what each one of the **Ekronites** said. But since he is referring to a group of people and ascribes this quotation to a plural subject, it may be more natural in your language to use plural pronouns within the quotation. Alternate translation: [They have brought around to us the Box of the God of Israel to kill all of us]

Here the people of Ekron are not using the pronoun **they** to refer to specific people. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [The Box of the God of Israel has been brought around to me] or [The Box of the God of Israel has been brought around to us]
By **people**, the Ekronites mean their families. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and my family]
